dt: {bc}to swing slowly and rhythmically back and forth from a base or pivot
{bc}to move gently from an upright to a leaning position
{bc}to hold sway {bc}act as ruler or governor
{bc}to fluctuate or veer between one point, position, or opinion and another
{bc}to cause to sway {bc}set to swinging, rocking, or oscillating
{bc}to cause to bend downward to one side
{bc}to exert a guiding or controlling influence on

pt: {sc}swing{/sc} {sc}sway{/sc} {sc}oscillate{/sc} {sc}vibrate{/sc} {sc}fluctuate{/sc} {sc}waver{/sc} {sc}undulate{/sc} mean to move from one direction to its opposite. {sc}swing{/sc} implies a movement of something attached at one end or one side.
{sc}sway{/sc} implies a slow swinging or teetering movement.
{sc}oscillate{/sc} stresses a usually regular alternation of direction.
{sc}vibrate{/sc} suggests the rapid oscillation of an elastic body under stress or impact.
{sc}fluctuate{/sc} suggests constant irregular changes of level, intensity, or value.
{sc}waver{/sc} stresses irregular motion suggestive of reeling or tottering.

{sc}affect{/sc} {sc}influence{/sc} {sc}touch{/sc} {sc}impress{/sc} {sc}strike{/sc} {sc}sway{/sc} mean to produce or have an effect upon. {sc}affect{/sc} implies the action of a stimulus that can produce a response or reaction.
{sc}influence{/sc} implies a force that brings about a change (as in nature or behavior).

pt.t: our beliefs are {it}influenced{/it} by our upbringing

pt: {sc}touch{/sc} may carry a vivid suggestion of close contact and may connote stirring, arousing, or harming.

pt.t: his emotions were {it}touched{/it} by her distress

pt: {sc}impress{/sc} stresses the depth and persistence of the effect.

pt.t: only one of the plans {it}impressed{/it} him

pt: {sc}strike{/sc}, similar to but weaker than {it}impress{/it}, may convey the notion of sudden sharp perception or appreciation.

pt.t: {it}struck{/it} by the solemnity of the occasion

pt: {sc}sway{/sc} implies the acting of influences that are not resisted or are irresistible, with resulting change in character or course of action.

pt.t: politicians who are {it}swayed{/it} by popular opinion

et: alteration of earlier {it}swey{/it} to fall, swoon, from Middle English {it}sweyen{/it}, probably of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Norse {it}sveigja{/it} to sway; akin to Lithuanian {it}svaigti{/it} to become dizzy
shortdef: to swing slowly and rhythmically back and forth from a base or pivot
to move gently from an upright to a leaning position
to hold sway : act as ruler or governor

dt: {bc}the action or an instance of {a_link|swaying} or of being {a_link|swayed} {bc}an oscillating, fluctuating, or sweeping motion
{bc}an inclination or deflection caused by or as if by swaying
{bc}the ability to exercise influence or authority {bc}{sx|dominance||}

pt: {sc}power{/sc} {sc}authority{/sc} {sc}jurisdiction{/sc} {sc}control{/sc} {sc}command{/sc} {sc}sway{/sc} {sc}dominion{/sc} mean the right to govern or rule or determine. {sc}power{/sc} implies possession of ability to wield force, authority, or influence.
{sc}authority{/sc} implies power for a specific purpose within specified limits.

pt.t: granted the {it}authority{/it} to manage her estate

pt: {sc}jurisdiction{/sc} applies to official power exercised within prescribed limits.
{sc}control{/sc} stresses the power to direct and restrain.

pt.t: you are responsible for the students under your {it}control{/it}

pt: {sc}command{/sc} implies the power to make arbitrary decisions and compel obedience.
{sc}sway{/sc} suggests the extent of exercised power or influence.

pt.t: the empire extended its {it}sway{/it} over the region

pt: {sc}dominion{/sc} stresses sovereign power or supreme authority.

shortdef: the action or an instance of swaying or of being swayed : an oscillating, fluctuating, or sweeping motion
an inclination or deflection caused by or as if by swaying
